misconceptions.inferred_category_name: Sorting One Parallel Array Automatically Reorders the Other
misconceptions.student_thought_process: The student believes that calling Arrays.sort(scores) will sort the scores and keep each score matched with its corresponding name in the names array, so that names[n-1] will be the name of the student with the highest score after sorting.
misconceptions.conceptual_gap: In Java, Arrays.sort(scores) only rearranges the elements inside the scores array. It does not (and cannot) automatically rearrange a separate array (names) to preserve pairings. Parallel arrays must be swapped in tandem during sorting (or you must sort indices / use objects like a Student class). After sorting only scores, names remains in original input order, so names[n-1] is just the last-entered name, not the name of the max score.
misconceptions.error_manifestation: Wrong output: prints the correct top score (max score) but often the wrong student name (typically the last name entered).

misconceptions.student_thought_process: The student believes that if two arrays are logically treated as parallel (sharing indices), performing a sorting operation on one array will automatically reorder the elements of the other array to maintain the relationship between data points.
misconceptions.conceptual_gap: In Java, arrays are independent objects in memory. The Arrays.sort() method only accepts a single array reference and has no awareness of other arrays that the programmer intends to keep synchronized. When the scores array is reordered, the indices of specific scores change, but the names array remains in its original order, breaking the link between names and their corresponding scores.

misconceptions.inferred_category_name: Parallel arrays stay aligned when sorting one array
misconceptions.student_thought_process: The student believes that calling Arrays.sort(scores) will either (a) also reorder the names array in the same way, or (b) keep the name-score pairing intact by index even though only scores is sorted.
misconceptions.conceptual_gap:
In Java, arrays have no built-in relationship to each other. Arrays.sort(scores) only permutes the elements inside the scores array; it does not (and cannot) automatically apply the same swaps to names. 

Trace with the sample input (N=3; names: Alice Bob Charlie; scores: 85 92 78):
- After reading inputs (end of line 22):
  - names = ["Alice", "Bob", "Charlie"]
  - scores = [85, 92, 78]
- After sorting (line 24):
  - scores becomes [78, 85, 92]
  - names remains ["Alice", "Bob", "Charlie"]
- Then (lines 26–28):
  - indexTop = 2
  - topName = names[2] = "Charlie" (still last-entered name)
  - topScore = scores[2] = 92 (now the maximum score)
So the program prints "Charlie (92)", but mathematically the student with score 92 is Bob. The intended behavior (top student’s name matching the top score) diverges right after line 24 because the parallel arrays are no longer aligned.
misconceptions.error_manifestation: Wrong output (prints the wrong student name paired with the highest score).

misconceptions.student_thought_process: The student believes that sorting the `scores` array will automatically maintain the correspondence between the `names` and `scores` arrays. They think that when they find the highest score at index `n-1` in the sorted scores array, the corresponding name will still be at index `n-1` in the names array.
misconceptions.conceptual_gap: The student lacks understanding of how parallel arrays work. When `Arrays.sort(scores)` is called, it only sorts the `scores` array. The `names` array remains unchanged. The index correspondence between the two arrays is broken—the student conflates a single index position with the paired data. After sorting only `scores`, `scores[n-1]` contains the highest score (92), but `names[n-1]` is still "Charlie" (the name that was originally at that position), not "Bob" (the name whose score is 92). Both arrays must be sorted synchronously for parallel arrays to work correctly.
misconceptions.error_manifestation: Wrong output. The program outputs 'Top student: Charlie (92)' instead of the expected 'Top student: Bob (92)'. The highest score (92) is correctly identified, but it is paired with the wrong name.

misconceptions.student_thought_process: The student believes that because 'names' and 'scores' were populated using the same indices to represent related data, sorting the 'scores' array will automatically trigger a corresponding reordering of the 'names' array to keep the pairs intact.
misconceptions.conceptual_gap: Java arrays are independent objects in memory. The 'Arrays.sort()' method only has access to the single array passed to it; it cannot see or modify other arrays that the programmer conceptually considers 'parallel'. When one array is sorted independently, the index-based relationship between the two arrays is destroyed.
